title: Sheffield United owner Prince Abdullah made £90,000 donation to controversial US group
text:
Sheffield United owner Prince Abdullah gave more than £90,000 to a controversial Muslim civil rights group which divides opinion in the USA.

The Saudi prince, who is in the process of taking full control at Bramall Lane after winning a High Court dispute, donated the money to the Council on American-Islamic Relations in May 2007.

They are a non-profit organisation formed 25 years ago to provide legal support and fight prejudice against Muslims.

Prince Abdullah has been involved in dispute with Sheffield United co-owner Kevin McCabe

This donation was made, however, at a time when US prosecutors listed CAIR among 250 unindicted co-conspirators in a high-profile trial in which individuals from the Holy Land Foundation, a large Islamic charity, were convicted after a retrial for supplying funds to militant groups including Hamas.

Prince Abdullah insists his donation was earmarked for educational activities. He says he was unaware of the story about the trial and has made no further payments.

'This was a single donation made more than 10 years ago,' the Prince told Sportsmail. 'It was made in good faith and represents a small portion of my annual charitable giving. That can't be a bad thing. I don't think it is relevant to anything any more.'

While CAIR has been accused of ties to Islamic extremism, they have denounced violence, been praised for their civil rights work and attracted popular support amid US president Donald Trump's attempts to impose a Muslim travel ban.

The Saudi prince became involved with the Blades when the club were in League One in 2013

Prince Abdullah bin Mosaad bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has been involved at Sheffield United since 2013, when he accepted an offer to buy half of the club — then in League One — on the agreement he would invest £10million.

He fell out with co-owner Kevin McCabe and a power struggle led to the High Court earlier this year, when it was revealed the Prince had borrowed money for the Blades from Saleh bin Laden.

The Bin Ladens are a respected business family in Saudi Arabia and have long since disowned Osama Bin Laden, but the surname is synonymous in the west with Al-Qaeda and terrorism.

Prince Abdullah, 54, is in the process of taking full control at Sheffield United

'I get offended when the Bin Laden family is given a bad name,' said Prince Abdullah after the judge had ruled in his favour. 'Every family may have one black sheep but they are very respectable.'

McCabe must sell his half of the club, now in the Premier League, to Prince Abdullah for £5m. Prince Abdullah must also buy from McCabe club properties, which include the stadium and training ground and are thought to be worth a total in excess of £50m.

The court will reconvene on Monday when it will become clear whether McCabe plans to contest the ruling. Prince Abdullah has installed his son-in-law Prince Musa'ad bin Khalid bin Abdulrahman Al Saud as chairman of Sheffield United.
description: EXCLUSIVE BY MATT BARLOW: Sheffield United owner Prince Abdullah gave more than £90,000 to a controversial Muslim civil rights group which divides opinion in the United States.
authors: Matt Barlow For The Daily Mail
